articles.headline: ‘We Need Answers’: Hurricane Michael Leaves Florida Residents Desperate for Aid
articles.snippet: “When is anybody coming to do something?” one woman asked as Panhandle residents began searching for basic necessities.
articles.abstract: “When is anybody coming to do something?” one woman asked as Panhandle residents began searching for basic necessities.
articles.lead_paragraph: PANAMA CITY, Fla. — It was two days after Hurricane Michael, and Eddie Foster was pushing his mother in a wheelchair down a thoroughly smashed street, his face creased with a concentrated dose of the frustration and fear that has afflicted much of the Florida Panhandle since the brutal storm turned its coast to rubble.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Audra D. S. Burch and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: California Tenants Take Rent Control Fight to the Ballot Box
articles.snippet: An initiative to loosen state restraints on local rent restrictions is the focus of a political battle being fought with tens of millions of dollars.
articles.abstract: An initiative to loosen state restraints on local rent restrictions is the focus of a political battle being fought with tens of millions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From pulpits across Los Angeles, Pastor Kelvin Sauls has spent the past few months delivering sermons on the spiritual benefits of fasting. The food in the sermon is rent, and landlords need less of it. “My role is to bring a moral perspective to what we are dealing with around the housing crisis,” Pastor Sauls explained.

articles.headline: Why Italy Could Be the Epicenter of the Next Financial Crisis
articles.snippet: The Italian government has defied eurozone rules with a lavish spending plan and squandered credibility with bond investors. The turmoil could rock the globe.
articles.abstract: The Italian government has defied eurozone rules with a lavish spending plan and squandered credibility with bond investors. The turmoil could rock the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: History suggests that the world is about due for another financial crisis. One of the places it might start, according to a growing number of indicators, is Italy.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Jason Horowitz

articles.headline: With Market Hot, Landlords Slam the Door on Section 8 Tenants
articles.snippet: Many landlords are now refusing to accept vouchers when they can get higher rents, without the bureaucratic red tape, on the open market.
articles.abstract: Many landlords are now refusing to accept vouchers when they can get higher rents, without the bureaucratic red tape, on the open market.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — One morning last year, Michele Carter woke up to find an eviction notice slipped under her apartment door. She had to move, she was later told, to make way for the renovation of her high-rise and the higher-paying tenants it would bring.

articles.headline: Costly Rehab for the Dying Is on the Rise at Nursing Homes, a Study Says
articles.snippet: Patients near death are increasingly getting high levels of physical, occupational and speech therapy, raising questions about the true purpose of such services.
articles.abstract: Patients near death are increasingly getting high levels of physical, occupational and speech therapy, raising questions about the true purpose of such services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nursing home residents on the verge of death are increasingly receiving intense levels of rehabilitation therapy in their final weeks and days, raising questions about whether such services are helpful or simply a lucrative source of revenue.

articles.headline: Facebook Says Russian Firms ‘Scraped’ Data, Some for Facial Recognition
articles.snippet: On the same day the company announced it had purged domestic sources of disinformation, it said it had blocked two companies, one of them with Russian government clients.
articles.abstract: On the same day the company announced it had purged domestic sources of disinformation, it said it had blocked two companies, one of them with Russian government clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On the same day Facebook announced that it had carried out its biggest purge yet of American accounts peddling disinformation, the company quietly made another revelation: It had removed 66 accounts, pages and apps linked to Russian firms that build facial recognition software for the Russian government.

articles.headline: The Leaders Who Unleashed China’s Mass Detention of Muslims
articles.snippet: A trail of online evidence establishes how President Xi Jinping and other senior officials adopted a tough new policy to assimilate ethnic minorities.
articles.abstract: A trail of online evidence establishes how President Xi Jinping and other senior officials adopted a tough new policy to assimilate ethnic minorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Rukiya Maimaiti, a local propaganda official in China’s far west, warned her colleagues to steel themselves for a wrenching task: detaining large numbers of ethnic Uighurs and other Muslim minorities.

articles.headline: As Suburban Women Turn to Democrats, Many Suburban Men Stand With Trump
articles.snippet: Suburban men, focused largely on economic issues, constitute a potential bulwark for President Trump in many of the suburban districts that will determine control of the House.
articles.abstract: Suburban men, focused largely on economic issues, constitute a potential bulwark for President Trump in many of the suburban districts that will determine control of the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — Robert Peters and George Fidelibus walked off the 18th green at the Golf Club of Dublin, then carried pints of beer to the patio overlooking the course, which was framed by $500,000 homes.

articles.headline: Jared Kushner Paid No Federal Income Tax for Years, Documents Suggest
articles.snippet: Confidential documents reviewed by The Times indicate that Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law and adviser, probably paid little or no income tax from 2009 to 2016.
articles.abstract: Confidential documents reviewed by The Times indicate that Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law and adviser, probably paid little or no income tax from 2009 to 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, Jared Kushner’s family company has spent billions of dollars buying real estate. His personal stock investments have soared. His net worth has quintupled to almost $324 million.
articles.byline: By Jesse Drucker and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: ‘Davos in the Desert,’ a Saudi Prince’s Glittering Showcase, Is Stained by a Grisly Accusation
articles.snippet: A conference for big investors started last year by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has become a symbol of the West’s deepening disillusionment with him after the disappearance of a Saudi journalist.
articles.abstract: A conference for big investors started last year by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has become a symbol of the West’s deepening disillusionment with him after the disappearance of a Saudi journalist.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The participants nicknamed it “Davos in the Desert,” which captures the lofty ambitions of the annual investor conference scheduled to convene in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, this month.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: Sears, the Original Everything Store, Files for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The retail chain struggled to adapt to changes in how Americans shop and engaged in risky financial engineering, racking up big losses.
articles.abstract: The retail chain struggled to adapt to changes in how Americans shop and engaged in risky financial engineering, racking up big losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sears, which more than a century ago pioneered the strategy of selling everything to everyone, filed for bankruptcy protection early on Monday and laid out a plan for turning its business around.

articles.headline: Democrats Want to Beat Scott Walker. But the Wisconsin Economy Is a Hurdle.
articles.snippet: As Mr. Walker, the Republican governor, seeks a third term, Democrats look for a way to successfully make an economic argument in a state where the indicators are strong.
articles.abstract: As Mr. Walker, the Republican governor, seeks a third term, Democrats look for a way to successfully make an economic argument in a state where the indicators are strong.
articles.lead_paragraph: RACINE, Wis. — This city’s downtown was all but empty on a recent Sunday afternoon, but one storefront office was so packed with Democrats that people had to wait outside.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Jeff Hawkins Is Finally Ready to Explain His Brain Research
articles.snippet: He created the mobile computing companies Palm and Handspring. But for decades his passion has been studying how the human brain works.
articles.abstract: He created the mobile computing companies Palm and Handspring. But for decades his passion has been studying how the human brain works.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. — In the global race to build artificial intelligence, it was a missed opportunity.

articles.headline: Trump Embraces Foreign Aid to Counter China’s Global Influence
articles.snippet: The move is a significant reversal for the president. A new agency will provide $60 billion in financing aimed at blocking Beijing’s ambitions.
articles.abstract: The move is a significant reversal for the president. A new agency will provide $60 billion in financing aimed at blocking Beijing’s ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump, seeking to counter China’s growing geopolitical influence, is embracing a major expansion of foreign aid that will bankroll infrastructure projects in Africa, Asia and the Americas — throwing his support behind an initiative he once sought to scuttle.

articles.headline: Wall St. Pins Hopes on Strong Earnings After October’s Ugly Start for Stocks
articles.snippet: The quarterly parade of updates on profits and losses will either give credence to fears about the economy or ease them.
articles.abstract: The quarterly parade of updates on profits and losses will either give credence to fears about the economy or ease them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week was all about fear. This week, investors could turn to greed.

articles.headline: In Trump’s Saudi Bargain, the Bottom Line Proudly Wins Out
articles.snippet: President Trump has resisted pressure to postpone or cancel arms sales to Saudi Arabia despite reports that a Saudi journalist was killed and dismembered.
articles.abstract: President Trump has resisted pressure to postpone or cancel arms sales to Saudi Arabia despite reports that a Saudi journalist was killed and dismembered.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump made Saudi Arabia his first foreign destination after taking office last year, he struck what amounted to a fundamental bargain with the royal family: He would not lecture them about human rights, and they would buy plenty of American weapons and military hardware.

articles.headline: Among the Ruins of Mexico Beach Stands One House, Built ‘for the Big One’
articles.snippet: Hurricane Michael wrecked every other beachfront house on the block, but one came through the storm nearly pristine, as if protected by grace. How did it survive?
articles.abstract: Hurricane Michael wrecked every other beachfront house on the block, but one came through the storm nearly pristine, as if protected by grace. How did it survive?
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO BEACH, Fla. — As they built their dream house last year on the shimmering sands of the Gulf of Mexico, Russell King and his nephew, Dr. Lebron Lackey, painstakingly documented every detail of the elevated construction, from the 40-foot pilings buried into the ground to the types of screws drilled into the walls. They picked gleaming paints from a palette of shore colors, chose salt-tolerant species to plant in the beach dunes and christened their creation the Sand Palace of Mexico Beach.

articles.headline: Reality Breaks Up a Saudi Prince Charming’s Media Narrative
articles.snippet: The media was happy to sing his praises in the spring, when the crown prince met with Hollywood stars and Silicon Valley titans. Then came the Jamal Khashoggi story.
articles.abstract: The media was happy to sing his praises in the spring, when the crown prince met with Hollywood stars and Silicon Valley titans. Then came the Jamal Khashoggi story.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just six months ago, American media outlets presented a sunny-side-up portrait of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia as he made a good-will tour of New York, Hollywood and Silicon Valley.

articles.headline: For Khashoggi, a Tangled Mix of Royal Service and Islamist Sympathies
articles.snippet: Jamal Khashoggi had both an affinity for Islamist political movements and close ties to the Saudi royal family — until they were cut by a new crown prince.
articles.abstract: Jamal Khashoggi had both an affinity for Islamist political movements and close ties to the Saudi royal family — until they were cut by a new crown prince.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Jamal Khashoggi landed in Washington last fall, leaving behind a long list of bad news back home.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Kenyans Say Chinese Investment Brings Racism and Discrimination
articles.snippet: Episodes involving discriminatory behavior by the region’s growing Chinese work force have unsettled many Kenyans, particularly at a time when their government seeks closer ties with China.
articles.abstract: Episodes involving discriminatory behavior by the region’s growing Chinese work force have unsettled many Kenyans, particularly at a time when their government seeks closer ties with China.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUIRU, Kenya — Before last year, Richard Ochieng’, 26, could not recall experiencing racism firsthand.

articles.headline: Saudis May Admit Khashoggi Was Killed in Interrogation by Mistake
articles.snippet: President Trump echoed the possibility that Jamal Khashoggi was victim to “rogue killers.” The explanation shields the Saudi crown prince, who has cast himself as a moderate.
articles.abstract: President Trump echoed the possibility that Jamal Khashoggi was victim to “rogue killers.” The explanation shields the Saudi crown prince, who has cast himself as a moderate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia was preparing an alternative explanation of the fate of a dissident journalist on Monday, saying he died at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul two weeks ago in an interrogation gone wrong, according to a person familiar with the kingdom’s plans. In Washington, President Trump echoed the possibility that Jamal Khashoggi was the victim of “rogue killers.”
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris, David D. Kirkpatrick and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: Elizabeth Warren’s DNA Results Draw Rebuke from Trump and Raise Questions
articles.snippet: The Massachusetts Democrat, weighing a 2020 presidential run, rebuts President Trump’s mocking of her claims about her heritage, but the right and left remain skeptical.
articles.abstract: The Massachusetts Democrat, weighing a 2020 presidential run, rebuts President Trump’s mocking of her claims about her heritage, but the right and left remain skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is a racial taunt made by the president of the United States, not unlike his discredited claim that Barack Obama was not born in America.

articles.headline: A Genocide Incited on Facebook, With Posts From Myanmar’s Military
articles.snippet: With fake pages and sham accounts, the military targeted the mostly Muslim Rohingya minority group, said former military officials, researchers and civilian officials.
articles.abstract: With fake pages and sham accounts, the military targeted the mostly Muslim Rohingya minority group, said former military officials, researchers and civilian officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — They posed as fans of pop stars and national heroes as they flooded Facebook with their hatred. One said Islam was a global threat to Buddhism. Another shared a false story about the rape of a Buddhist woman by a Muslim man.
